subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Question about alternate letters in the Unicode proposal
msgSnippet: ... Yes, I remembered that one. It hardly seems like an alternate letter form to me. ... I realize that you re advocating a computational approach to Senior QS
messageBody:
On Nov 28, 2007 2:37 AM, Anthony Grahn <othermale@...> wrote:
>
>
>
>
>
>
> --- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "Ted Larson Freeman"
>
> <freeman@...> wrote:
> >
> >Could someone please point me to an example of the alternate letter
> >for May? I can't find it in the QM...
> >
>
> The May variation is implied on pg13 in the example for "mire" (and
> elsewhere)

Yes, I remembered that one. It hardly seems like an alternate letter form to me.

> >...and I don't see it in any of the QS fonts...
> >
>
> No font has ever been written to fully support QS. A few simulate a
> super tight kerning which is not remotely the same thing (obviously).
> Others include a few joined forms of vowel+Roe which has given rise to
> the erroneous notion that these are ligatures.

I realize that you're advocating a computational approach to Senior QS
(good luck!) that goes far beyond current fonts, but why do you say
that forms such as vowel+Roe are not ligatures?


> >Regarding the alternate letter for They, the QM only says "Letter No.8
> >may connect on the writing-line by an allowable extension upward and
> >forward..." This is on page 13
> >
>
> Which of course implies They has a variation. Unless of course someone
> imagines this can be done by the rendering layer (fyi it absolutely
> can not)

My point here was simply that Read did not consider this variation to
be an alternate letter.


> >True alternate letters are introduced on page 14
> >under "4 ALTERNATIVE LETTER-SYMBOLS".
> >
>
> pg 14, incidentally, is in the Senior section of the manual. Read's
> items under that heading intentionally omits those letter forms which
> are obvious from examples elsewhere in the interest of clarity and
> brevity.
>
>
> >
> >I'd be happier if we dropped May and They from this list.
> >
>
> The variations for No and Utter are mentioned in the senior section of
> the QM. Junior has no more need for the alternative form of No or
> Utter than it needs the alternative May or They.

Yes, but it's easy enough to include these in a list of QS
letters--much easier than trying to enumerate letter connections. (See
my next post.)


> I regret to say, quite the reverse, that the list of alternate letters
> in proposal.txt is not exhaustive: on the bottom of pg 15 the word
> "knife" shows a variation for Fee, the example for Sea+Pea at the
> bottom of pg 13 has similar implications etc. (there are likewise
> ligatures few seem to notice like Sea+Utter)
> IMO either the list in proposal.txt should be entirely dropped or it
> should be entirely complete.
>
> I know that the there is irresistible pressure for the Unicode
> proposal to be a snap shot of the first page of the QM. I recall
> reading a post wherein someone said they were "allergic to extra
> Unicode points for senior" which, as an argument, seems a tad weak to
> me. Personally I'd like to see it done carefully and completely and in
> consultation with persons with a full understanding of QS even if this
> slows the process but I've been avoiding the topic having notived that
> any proposal for completeness is futile.

I don't think it's futile at all--I just think you're the only one
who's going to do it. If you do, many of us will be quite interested
in what you produce.

Ted


> --- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "Ted Larson Freeman"
>
>
> <freeman@...> wrote:
> >
> > I have a quick question about the Unicode proposal. In the document
> > Files->Unicode Proposal->proposal.txt it says:
> >
> > The following letters have alternate forms:
> >
> > QUIKSCRIPT LETTER THEY
> > QUIKSCRIPT LETTER MAY
> > QUIKSCRIPT LETTER NO
> > QUIKSCRIPT LETTER UTTER
> >
> > Could someone please point me to an example of the alternate letter
> > for May? I can't find it in the QM, and I don't see it in any of the
> > QS fonts.
> >
> > Regarding the alternate letter for They, the QM only says "Letter No.8
> > may connect on the writing-line by an allowable extension upward and
> > forward..." This is on page 13 in "SECTION II: HOW LETTERS MAY BE
> > JOINED". This seems to me to be a senior QS connection style, not an
> > alternate letter. True alternate letters are introduced on page 14
> > under "4 ALTERNATIVE LETTER-SYMBOLS".
> >
> > I'd be happier if we dropped May and They from this list.
> >
> > Thanks.
> >
> > Ted
> >
>
>
